There isn’t zero indication. The kid talks about deleting family members. And the father is grieving the death of his dead wife that he calls the daughter by his wife’s name. He even cries in anguish, “Eriko!! Why you too... Eriko.” I mean there’s a lot of indications. The kid is the only one not sad about the death, only the father and stepdaughter. Or we can assume that the story is being played straight. I don’t think the guy beneath me bothered to actually read the story.

I agree with the last guy. Where are all these guys getting the idea of the kid killing the wives? Literally zero indication of that. When the kid was talking about “deleting family members” he was talking about his dad having him remove the wives’ names from a list they probably had, making the son take care of that due to the dad being a piece of shit. It’s not that deep. Just a story about a shitty bastard who finally got his comeuppance from a new step-daughter by killing him and fucking his son.

You people are looking for complexities when there are none, shits simple. Dad kills wives for insurance money, kid gets fucked in his head because his 'moms' keep dying that is why he is asking the girl if she is sad or not. Sex at the beginning is not really important, although it could be implied that the dad wants to marry his stepdaughter. Kid literally deletes people because they are dead already and he thinks that since the new mom is dead his 'sister' is going to leave as well since they aren't related or anything. Therefore he thinks he will have to delete her too. Girl kills the dad, they leave in the morning so the kid doesn't see what happened. The ending isn't even dark, the kids is just saying 'I won't be a kid anymore' and 'I will have a new family with my 'sister' '

Am I missing some panel or was there some prequel to this? I am not seeing this insurance agent you guys are referring to.
Whenever I read a fucked up plot line on an h-site, I soon stumble unto a reddit thread that tops that.

Unless there's a translation error, I think the last panel being black with those ominous lines makes it clear that the kid was the real killer.  The insurance agent THINKS the father is murdering wives because that's the obvious conclusion when someone's spouses keep dropping and there's insurance to pay out.  I mean, think about the kid asking if she was sad because her mother died.  He doesn't understand that emotion!
@MAG Well shit, i did not read it like that. That make sense too... meh anyway the kid get the girl so... yeah.

The whole "delete family member" is because the dad killed his previous two wives so for the kid, who knew his dad is responsable for their "death", it's a burden to "remember" the face of new mom, aka "new family member" since they are going to "leave" (die) anyway. I am more worried of the fact that the kid see himself in his father's role now...

4. The boy's desire is revealed to be "a family of this own." He had it when there were him, his father and his first mother. But his mother died (probably not killed in any way) and his father looked for a new wife. He doesn't acknowledge them so he kills them. He even intended to kill the daughter ("onee-chan who i was gonna delete too"). The proof: if he just "deleted" the family members he didn't want to remember "from the computer" because they had already been dead, then why did he intend to "delete" the daughter, who was still alive? It can only be explained that he didn't want to remember them in the first place. However, now that the young girl is going to be his wife and give birth to his child, they are now his own family.
@Warrior1 nope the "dad" is dead. She picked a knife for a reason. She killed her stepdad and ran away with her stepbrother.

1. The man, who is fucking the young girl, mourns her mother's name. This probably implies that he is truly grieving the lost of his new (and dead) wife. 

2. When the boy has sex, he almost slips out "I'll have a new... f-" F stands for family, further confirmed at the end. 

3. Nothing can confirm whether she does kill the man or not. Doesn't really affect the whole story anyway.
